categories.name: Government Requirements
categories.description: Mandatory government compliance requirements for Philippine employees

items.title: Social Security System (SSS)
items.content: The Social Security System (SSS) is a mandatory social insurance program that provides benefits to private sector employees. All employees earning at least ₱1,000 per month must be registered with SSS.

requirements.description: Employee must have an SSS number. If new employee doesn't have one, they need to register at any SSS branch or online through the SSS website.
requirements.howToComply: Visit https://www.sss.gov.ph or go to the nearest SSS branch. Bring valid ID and birth certificate.

requirements.description: Complete SSS Form E-1 (Employee Registration Form)
requirements.howToComply: HR will provide the form or download from SSS website

requirements.description: Monthly contributions are shared between employer and employee based on the monthly salary credit
requirements.howToComply: Automatically deducted from salary. Current contribution rate is 14% (9.5% employer, 4.5% employee)

faqs.question: SSS contribution?
faqs.answer: SSS contributions are based on your Monthly Salary Credit (MSC). The total contribution is 14% of your MSC, with 9.5% paid by the employer and 4.5% by the employee. For 2025, the minimum MSC is ₱4,000 and the maximum is ₱30,000.

faqs.question: What if I already have an SSS number from a previous employer?
faqs.answer: You should provide your existing SSS number to HR. Your employer will continue your contributions using the same SSS number. You don't need to register again.

faqs.question: Can I check my SSS contributions online?
faqs.answer: Yes! Register for My.SSS account at https://www.sss.gov.ph. You can view your contribution history, apply for benefits, and update personal information.

items.title: Philippine Health Insurance Corporation (PhilHealth)
items.content: PhilHealth is the national health insurance program that provides health coverage to all Filipino citizens and residents. It is mandatory for all employed individuals.

requirements.description: Employee must have a PhilHealth Identification Number. New members need to register.
requirements.howToComply: Register online at https://www.philhealth.gov.ph or visit any PhilHealth office with valid ID and birth certificate

requirements.description: Complete the PhilHealth Member Registration Form
requirements.howToComply: Download from PhilHealth website or get from HR department

requirements.description: Monthly premium is 5% of basic monthly salary (shared equally between employer and employee)
requirements.howToComply: Automatically deducted from salary - 2.5% employee share, 2.5% employer share

benefits: Z Benefits (catastrophic coverage for cancer, kidney disease, etc.)

faqs.question: How much is the PhilHealth contribution?
faqs.answer: For 2025, the premium rate is 5% of your basic monthly salary, with a minimum of ₱500 and maximum of ₱5,000 per month. This is split equally: 2.5% employer, 2.5% employee.

faqs.question: Can I use PhilHealth benefits immediately?
faqs.answer: For employed members, you can use PhilHealth benefits immediately after your employer remits your first contribution. There's no waiting period for employed members.

faqs.question: Can my dependents use my PhilHealth coverage?
faqs.answer: Yes! Your legal spouse, legitimate children under 21 years old (or up to 25 if still studying), and parents aged 60 and above can be registered as your dependents and use your PhilHealth benefits.

items.title: Home Development Mutual Fund (Pag-IBIG)
items.content: Pag-IBIG Fund (HDMF) is a mandatory savings program that helps employees save for housing and provides access to housing loans. All private and public sector employees must be members.

requirements.description: Employee needs a Pag-IBIG Member ID Number. Register if new member.
requirements.howToComply: Register online at https://www.pagibigfund.gov.ph or visit any Pag-IBIG branch with valid IDs
Available from HR or download from Pag-IBIG website

requirements.description: Monthly contributions based on salary bracket
requirements.howToComply: Automatically deducted from salary. Employee contributes 2% of monthly compensation, employer matches 2%

benefits: Savings program with dividends (higher than bank interest)

faqs.question: How much is the Pag-IBIG contribution?
faqs.answer: Employee contribution is 2% of monthly compensation (minimum ₱100). For those earning ₱1,500 or more, the minimum is ₱100 and maximum is ₱200 per month. The employer matches this amount.

faqs.question: When can I apply for a Pag-IBIG housing loan?
faqs.answer: You can apply for a housing loan after contributing for at least 24 months, with at least 1 month contribution in the last 6 months. The loan amount depends on your capacity to pay.

faqs.question: What is the Multi-Purpose Loan?
faqs.answer: MPL is a short-term loan available to members who have contributed for at least 24 months. You can borrow up to 80% of your total savings with affordable monthly amortization.

items.title: Tax Identification Number (TIN)
items.content: The Tax Identification Number (TIN) is a unique identifier issued by the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR). Every employee in the Philippines must have a TIN for tax purposes.

requirements.description: Employee must have a TIN. If new employee, they need to register with BIR.
requirements.howToComply: Register at the BIR Revenue District Office (RDO) where you reside. Employer can also process bulk TIN registration.

requirements.description: Application for Registration for Employees form
requirements.howToComply: HR will coordinate with BIR or employee can personally register

requirements.description: Present valid government-issued ID for verification
requirements.howToComply: Any government ID (Passport, Driver's License, Postal ID, etc.)

benefits: Receipt of BIR Form 2316 (Certificate of Compensation Payment/Tax Withheld)

faqs.question: Can I have more than one TIN?
faqs.answer: No! Having multiple TINs is illegal in the Philippines and punishable by law. You should use your existing TIN even when changing employers.

faqs.question: What if I forgot my TIN?
faqs.answer: You can retrieve your TIN by visiting any BIR office with a valid ID, calling the BIR hotline at 8538-3200, or checking your BIR Form 2316 from your previous employer.

faqs.question: Is withholding tax automatically deducted from my salary?
faqs.answer: Yes. Your employer is required to withhold the appropriate tax from your compensation based on the BIR withholding tax table and remit it to the BIR on your behalf.

items.title: BIR Form 2316 (Annual Certificate)
items.deadline: Issued by employer by January 31 of the following year
items.content: BIR Form 2316 is the Certificate of Compensation Payment/Tax Withheld. Employers must issue this to employees annually, showing total compensation and taxes withheld for the year.

requirements.description: Form issued for the entire tax year (January to December)
requirements.howToComply: HR will automatically generate this by January 31

requirements.description: If you transferred from another employer during the year, provide your previous employer's Form 2316
requirements.howToComply: Request from previous employer for tax filing purposes

benefits: Required for annual income tax return filing
Proof of income and tax payment

faqs.question: When will I receive my BIR Form 2316?
faqs.answer: Employers must issue Form 2316 on or before January 31 of the following year. For example, for 2025 income, you should receive it by January 31, 2026.

faqs.question: What if I resigned mid-year?
faqs.answer: Your employer must issue Form 2316 within 30 days from the date of separation, covering the period you worked with them.

faqs.question: Do I need to file an income tax return if I only have one employer?
faqs.answer: If you're a purely compensation income earner with only one employer, you're generally not required to file an annual ITR. However, filing is optional if you want to claim tax refunds or for documentation purposes.

categories.name: HR Policies & Guidelines
categories.description: Common HR policies in Philippine companies

items.title: Working Hours and Schedule
items.content: Standard working hours and schedules based on Philippine Labor Code and company policy.

details.description: The standard working hours in the Philippines is 8 hours per day, not exceeding 48 hours per week as mandated by the Labor Code.

Most companies follow a Monday to Friday schedule, 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM with 1 hour lunch break. Break time: 10:00-10:15 AM AND 3:00-3:15 PM. Some companies offer flexible schedules or compressed workweek arrangements.
Employees are entitled to a minimum 1-hour lunch break. Additional rest periods may be provided depending on company policy.
Many companies provide a 10-15 minute grace period for tardiness, though this varies by company policy.

faqs.question: What happens if I arrive late?
faqs.answer: Tardiness policies vary by company. Most companies have a grace period of 5-15 minutes. Beyond that, tardiness may be recorded and could affect attendance records or performance evaluation. Repeated tardiness may result in disciplinary action.

faqs.question: Can I work flexible hours?
faqs.answer: This depends on your company's policy and your role. Some companies offer flexible work arrangements, compressed workweeks, or work-from-home options. Discuss this with your supervisor or HR.

faqs.question: Am I required to log in my attendance?
faqs.answer: Yes. Companies are required by law to maintain employee time records. This is usually done through biometric systems, time cards, or digital time-tracking systems.

items.title: Leave Benefits
items.content: Philippine companies must comply with the Labor Code regarding leave benefits, with many offering additional benefits.

details.description: All employees who have worked for at least 1 year are entitled to 5 days of paid Service Incentive Leave annually. This can be used for vacation or sick leave.
Many companies offer additional vacation leave beyond the mandatory SIL. Common practice is 15 days annually for regular employees, though this varies by company.
Sick leave entitlement varies by company. Typically, companies provide 15 days annually. Medical certificate may be required for absences exceeding 2-3 consecutive days.
Female employees are entitled to 105 days of paid maternity leave (extended from 60 days under RA 11210). An additional 30 days unpaid leave may be granted.
Male employees are entitled to 7 days of paid paternity leave for the birth of their legitimate child or in case of miscarriage.
Solo parents are entitled to 7 working days of paid parental leave annually under the Solo Parents Welfare Act.
Female employees who undergo surgery due to gynecological disorders are entitled to special leave of up to 2 months with full pay.
Victims of Violence Against Women and Children are entitled to 10 days paid leave (RA 9262).
Some companies provide emergency leave for unforeseen circumstances. This is discretionary and varies by company policy.

faqs.question: How do I file for leave?
faqs.answer: Leave should be filed through your company's N-xpert portal. For planned leave (like vacation), file at least 5-7 days in advance. For sick leave, notify your supervisor immediately and submit medical certificate if required.

faqs.question: Can I convert unused leave to cash?
faqs.answer: This depends on company policy. Some companies allow leave conversion or carry-over to the next year, while others follow a 'use it or lose it' policy.

faqs.question: When can I start using my leave credits?
faqs.answer: Typically, leave credits are earned after completing the probationary period (usually 3-6 months). Some companies have a pro-rated system based on months of service.

faqs.question: What if I need to extend my maternity leave?
faqs.answer: After the 105 days of paid leave, you may file for an additional 30 days of unpaid leave or use available vacation leave credits.

items.title: Compensation and Payroll
items.content: Understanding your salary, deductions, and payroll schedule.

details.description: Minimum wage varies by region in the Philippines. As of 2025, Metro Manila minimum wage ranges from ₱610-₱645 per day depending on the sector. Check with DOLE for current rates in your region.
Salaries must be paid at least once every two weeks or twice a month. Most companies follow a semi-monthly schedule (15th and 30th/end of month).
All rank-and-file employees are entitled to 13th month pay, equivalent to 1/12 of the total basic salary earned within the calendar year. This must be paid on or before December 24.
The following are automatically deducted from your salary: Withholding Tax, SSS contribution (4.5%), PhilHealth (2.5%), and Pag-IBIG (2%).
Work beyond 8 hours is compensated with overtime pay at 125% of the hourly rate on regular days, 130% on rest days, and 200% on special holidays.
Employees working between 10 PM and 6 AM are entitled to a night shift differential of at least 10% of their regular wage.
Employees are entitled to 100% of their daily rate on regular holidays even if not working. Work on regular holidays is paid at 200% of daily rate.

faqs.question: When is my salary credited?
faqs.answer: Most companies process payroll on the 15th and 30th/last day of the month. If these dates fall on a weekend or holiday, payment is usually made on the preceding working day.

faqs.question: How is my 13th month pay calculated?
faqs.answer: 13th month pay = Total basic salary earned in the year ÷ 12. Only basic salary is included; allowances, overtime, and other benefits are not included in the computation unless specified by company policy.

faqs.question: Why are there deductions from my salary?
faqs.answer: Mandatory deductions include government contributions (SSS, PhilHealth, Pag-IBIG) and withholding tax. Other deductions may include company loans, insurance premiums, or other authorized deductions.

faqs.question: Is my 13th month pay taxable?
faqs.answer: 13th month pay and other bonuses up to ₱90,000 per year are tax-exempt. Any amount exceeding ₱90,000 is subject to withholding tax.

items.title: Probationary Period and Regularization
items.content: Understanding probationary employment and the path to regular status.

details.description: New employees typically undergo a probationary period of 3 to 6 months. During this time, the employer evaluates if the employee meets the standards for regular employment.
At the start of employment, the employer must inform you of the reasonable standards for regularization. These usually include job performance, attendance, and behavior.
Regular performance evaluations are conducted during the probationary period. Supervisors provide feedback on your progress toward meeting regularization standards.
If you meet the standards within the probationary period, you become a regular employee. Regular employees enjoy security of tenure and cannot be dismissed except for just or authorized causes.
Probationary period may be extended only if agreed upon in writing at the time of hiring and must not exceed 6 months total.

faqs.question: What happens if I don't pass the probationary period?
faqs.answer: If you fail to meet the standards communicated at hiring, your employment may be terminated. However, employers must follow due process and provide valid reasons for termination during probation.

faqs.question: Do I receive benefits during probation?
faqs.answer: Yes! Probationary employees are entitled to government-mandated benefits (SSS, PhilHealth, Pag-IBIG), minimum wage, and holiday pay. Some company benefits may be available only after regularization.

faqs.question: When will I know if I'm regularized?
faqs.answer: You should receive formal notice of regularization before or upon completion of your probationary period. If no notice is given and you continue working beyond 6 months, you are automatically considered regular.

faqs.question: Can I resign during probation?
faqs.answer: Yes, probationary employees can resign but must provide the required notice period (usually 30 days or as stated in the contract).

items.title: Health and Safety
items.content: Occupational health and safety requirements in Philippine workplaces.

details.description: Under DOLE regulations, employers must provide a safe and healthy workplace. This includes proper ventilation, lighting, sanitation facilities, and safety equipment.
Pre-employment medical examination is typically required. Annual physical examinations may be provided as part of company benefits or as required for specific industries.
Many companies provide Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) coverage as an additional benefit beyond PhilHealth. Coverage details vary by company.
Companies must comply with current health protocols including vaccination policies, health declarations, and workplace safety measures as mandated by government agencies.
Any work-related accident or injury must be reported immediately to HR and your supervisor. Employees injured on the job are entitled to workers' compensation.

faqs.question: What should I do if I feel unsafe at work?
faqs.answer: Report safety concerns immediately to your supervisor or HR. The company is legally obligated to address safety hazards and maintain a safe working environment.

faqs.question: Am I covered if I get injured at work?
faqs.answer: Yes. Work-related injuries are covered by the Employees' Compensation Program (ECP) through SSS or GSIS. You may be entitled to medical benefits, sickness allowance, or disability benefits.

faqs.question: Is the pre-employment medical exam mandatory?
faqs.answer: While not strictly mandated by law for all positions, most companies require it to ensure fitness for work and to establish a health baseline.

items.title: Code of Conduct and Discipline
items.content: Workplace behavior expectations and disciplinary procedures.

details.description: Employees are expected to maintain professional behavior, respect colleagues, follow company policies, and perform duties diligently.
Common prohibited acts include: dishonesty, theft, insubordination, harassment, disclosure of confidential information, and serious misconduct.
Violations may result in disciplinary action ranging from verbal warning to written warning, suspension, or termination depending on severity.
Employees subject to disciplinary action are entitled to due process: notice of the charge, opportunity to explain, and notice of decision.
Most companies have dress code policies ranging from business formal to business casual. Check your employee handbook or ask HR for specific guidelines.

faqs.question: What constitutes serious misconduct?
faqs.answer: Serious misconduct includes acts like fraud, theft, physical violence, serious insubordination, or gross negligence that causes significant harm to the company or other employees.

faqs.question: What are my rights during a disciplinary investigation?
faqs.answer: You have the right to be informed of the charges against you, to present your side and evidence, and to be assisted by a representative if desired. Employers must follow proper due process.

faqs.question: Can I be fired immediately?
faqs.answer: Termination for just cause (serious misconduct) or authorized cause (redundancy, retrenchment) must follow due process. Immediate dismissal without notice is only valid for serious and grave offenses with proper documentation.

items.title: Resignation and Separation
items.content: Process and requirements when leaving the company.

details.description: Employees must provide written notice of resignation at least 30 days before the intended date of separation. Probationary employees may have different notice requirements.
Resigning employees must complete clearance from all departments, return company property, and settle any outstanding accountabilities before final pay release.
Final pay includes unpaid salary, unused leave credits (if convertible), pro-rated 13th month pay, and other benefits. Must be released within 30 days from separation.
Employees are entitled to request a Certificate of Employment indicating position, length of service, and duties performed.
Separation pay is required for authorized causes (redundancy, retrenchment, closure not due to serious misconduct). Not required for voluntary resignation or dismissal for just cause.

faqs.question: Can I leave immediately after filing resignation?
faqs.answer: Generally no. You must serve the 30-day notice period unless waived by management. Leaving without rendering notice may result in forfeiture of benefits or legal action.

faqs.question: When will I receive my final pay?
faqs.answer: By law, final pay should be released within 30 days from date of separation or as specified in company policy, whichever is earlier.

faqs.question: What documents will I receive upon separation?
faqs.answer: You should receive: Certificate of Employment (COE), BIR Form 2316, final pay computation statement, and clearance certificate upon completion of clearance process.

faqs.question: Can I use my remaining leave credits?
faqs.answer: This depends on company policy. Some companies allow leave credits to be used during the notice period, while others convert unused credits to cash as part of final pay.

items.title: Performance Management
items.content: Understanding performance evaluation and career growth.

details.description: Most companies conduct formal performance evaluations annually or semi-annually. Evaluations assess job performance, achievements, and areas for improvement.
Employees and supervisors typically set performance goals and key performance indicators (KPIs) at the beginning of the evaluation period.
Companies may offer training programs, workshops, certifications, and career advancement opportunities for employee development.
Promotions are typically based on performance, qualifications, experience, and available positions. Criteria vary by company.
Employees not meeting performance standards may be placed on a PIP, which outlines specific goals and timelines for improvement.

faqs.question: How often will my performance be evaluated?
faqs.answer: Most companies conduct formal evaluations annually or semi-annually. Informal feedback and check-ins may occur more frequently.

faqs.question: What happens if I receive a poor performance rating?
faqs.answer: Poor ratings typically lead to discussions about improvement, additional training, or placement on a Performance Improvement Plan (PIP). Consistently poor performance may lead to termination if standards aren't met.

faqs.question: Can I request training or development opportunities?
faqs.answer: Yes! Discuss your career goals and development needs with your supervisor during performance reviews or one-on-one meetings. Many companies support employee development.

items.title: Data Privacy and Confidentiality
items.content: Protection of personal information and company confidential data under the Data Privacy Act of 2012 (RA 10173).

details.description: Your employer must comply with the Data Privacy Act. Your personal information is collected, processed, and stored securely for employment purposes only.
You have the right to access, correct, or request deletion of your personal data. You also have the right to be informed how your data is used and to object to certain processing.
Employees must not disclose company confidential information including trade secrets, client data, financial information, or proprietary processes.
Many companies require employees to sign an NDA to protect sensitive information during and after employment.

faqs.question: What personal information does the company collect?
faqs.answer: Typically: name, address, contact information, government IDs, educational background, employment history, and family information for benefits purposes. All data is used solely for employment and legal compliance.

faqs.question: Can I request a copy of my personal data?
faqs.answer: Yes. Under the Data Privacy Act, you can request access to your personal data held by the company.

faqs.question: What happens if I accidentally share confidential information?
faqs.answer: Report the incident immediately to HR or your supervisor. Depending on the severity and intent, this may result in disciplinary action.

details.description: Companies may offer remote work, hybrid arrangements, or full work-from-home setup depending on business needs and job requirements.
Employers may provide necessary equipment (laptop, internet allowance) for remote work. Employees are responsible for maintaining a suitable work environment.
Remote employees must adhere to agreed work schedules and remain accessible during working hours.
Performance is measured by output and deliverables. Some companies use time-tracking or project management tools.
Remote workers must ensure secure internet connections, protect company devices, and follow data security protocols.

faqs.question: Am I eligible for work-from-home?
faqs.answer: Eligibility depends on your role, performance, and company policy. Discuss with your supervisor or HR to explore remote work options.

faqs.question: Will I receive equipment for working from home?
faqs.answer: This varies by company. Some provide laptops and allowances, while others expect employees to use their own equipment. Check with HR.

faqs.question: What if I have technical issues while working remotely?
faqs.answer: Contact your company's IT support immediately. Document issues that prevent you from working and inform your supervisor.

faqs.question: Who should I contact for payroll concerns?
faqs.answer: Contact the HR or visit the HR office or email.

faqs.question: Who do I contact for IT support?
faqs.answer: Contact the HR to help you.

faqs.question: Can I install software on my work laptop?
faqs.answer: No. All software installations must be requested through IT Helpdesk to ensure security and licensing compliance.

faqs.question: What should I do if my equipment is not working?
faqs.answer: Contact the IT Helpdesk with details of the issue. For critical equipment failures, call the helpdesk directly.
